titleStmt.title: CORALS: Who are My Potential New Customers? Tapping into the Wisdom of Customers' Decisions

analytic.title: CORALS: Who are My Potential New Customers? Tapping into the Wisdom of Customers' Decisions

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Identifying and recommending potential new customers for local businesses are crucial to the survival and success of local businesses. A key component to identifying the right customers is to understand their decision-making processes of choosing one business over the others. However, modeling this process is an extremely challenging task as a decision is in uenced by multiple factors. ese factors include, but not limited to an individual's taste or preference, the location and accessibility of a business, and the reputation of a business from the social media. Existing recommender systems focus on recommending related businesses to customers. Even though these models present the potential to recommend customers to businesses, they lack the power to integrate multiple factors together. In this paper, we introduce a customer recommendation model, CORALS, which considers the personal preferences of di erent customers, the geographical in uence, and the reputation of local businesses. To evaluate the proposed model, we conduct a series of experiments to extensively compare with nine state-of-the-art methods using two real-world datasets. e results demonstrate that CORALS outperforms all these baselines by a signi cant margin in most scenarios. In addition to identifying potential new customers, we also break down the analysis for different types of businesses to evaluate the impact of various factors that may a ect customers' decisions. is information, in return, provides a great resource for local businesses to adjust their advertising strategies and business services to a ract more prospective customers.

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: Recommender system has a racted substantial a ention from academia since the last decade and has revolutionized the e-commerce industry. Various recommender systems have been developed to facilitate the matching between customers with appropriate products or services, such as movies on Net ix, music on Last.fm, and merchandises on Amazon. For customers, recommendations improve user experience by providing helpful suggestions to explore and discover relevant products or services. For product and service providers, these recommendations increase the propensity of purchases from customers.

Over the past few years, the prevalence of GPS-enabled devices, such as smart phones, establish the prosperity of location-based social networks (LBSN), such as Foursquare, Yelp, and Facebook Places. LBSN a racts millions of users to share their social friendship and their locations via check-ins. For example, an average of 142 million users check in at local businesses via Yelp every month [42]. Foursquare has 55 millions monthly active users and 8 millions daily check-ins on the Swarm application [33]. Facebook places has about 1.8 million check-ins worldwide every day [2]. e check-in information not only contains abundant hints of user preferences on locations but also provides an important dimension in understanding human mobility, which paves the way to the success of recommender systems in LBSN. In LBSN, the majority of existing research studies focus on point-of-interest (POI) recommendation, which aims to suggest unvisited POIs given the current time and location of a customer. Here, a POI refers to a geographic entity such as a landmark, a school, a historical building or a local business. For local businesses, we highlight that instead of passively waiting for customers to explore and discover themselves through POI recommendations, local businesses can actively send coupons and incentives to a ract potential new customers. erefore, how to precisely identify potential new customers and e ciently help them get on board are crucial to the survival and success of the local businesses. In the industry, potential new customer identi cation is a key component in customer acquisition. For example, Google Adwords uses multiple signals, such as online forms 1 , to target and identify potential new Adwords customers. Facebook develops Facebook Pixel to help businesses target new people who do not know them 2 .

To identify potential new customers, the most crucial thing is to understand a customer's decision-making process. However, it is a complex process, and can be in uenced by multiple factors. Most investigated factors are personal preferences and geographical convenience. Personal preferences are learned from customers' historical check-ins by applying collaborative ltering or matrix factorization techniques. e learned preferences, in return, help us nd out new businesses which customers are interested in. In addition, check-in locations provide a novel resource to interpret customers' decisions from the perspective of geographical convenience. According to the Tobler's rst law of geography and the law of demand, the propensity of a customer for a local business is inversely proportional to the distance between the customer and the business, which is similar to the probability of purchasing an item inversely proportional to the cost.

ere are also studies which show that customers prefer learning from local experts who know the neighborhood well and have rst-hand experience [1]. is is because that online reviews are becoming more and more in uential in establishing and promoting the reputation of local businesses than ever before. e emergence of numerous review sites has created an unprecedented, ongoing online conversation about local businesses. erefore, a business' reputation is more public and more accessible. Customers are able to see over the "wall" of corporate messaging at what lies behind. ey can get a sense of a business' true essence through the shared experiences of other customers. ese changes in marketing lead to the change of customers' habits. Customers are becoming more and more review-dependent.

is is consistent with the study conducted by BrightLocal [27]. Compared with the trend in 2010, there are more people (2X) who will search for a local business before consumption than in 2015 and 2016. Moreover, among all the participants in the study, 92% of the customers regularly or occasionally read online reviews, which help them judge whether a local business provides good services or not. erefore, the impact of online reviews is non-negligible and growing.
Although identifying potential new customers is crucial for local businesses, it is still a very challenging task due to the following three reasons.

• Data Sparsity. To know and comment on a local business, a customer has to physically visit that business. us, the cost is higher than that of rating a movie or a song online. Even though a customer makes the e ort to visit the business, he/she o en does not check in due to privacy or safety concerns [39], let alone writing a review. erefore, customers' check-in data is much sparser than other rating data for movies and music. Table 1 shows the statistics and the densities of four well-known movie and music rating datasets 3 , together with two LBSN datasets, i.e. the Yelp challenge dataset 4 and a Foursquare dataset 5 . Here the density is calculated by the number of ratings/check-ins divided by the product of the number of users and the number of items/businesses. e densities of Yelp and Foursquare datasets are much lower than the ones of Net ix, MovieLens, Last.fm, and Yahoo! music datasets. e extremely sparse check-in data makes it challenging for us to accurately model customers' preferences; therefore, it imposes the needs of smarter learning algorithms which are more suited for sparse data. • Geographical In uence.

e rst law of geography states that everything is related to everything else, but near things are more related than distant things [34]. Many studies show that people tend to visit nearby local businesses or explore businesses near the ones that they have visited before [41].

erefore, a challenge is how to estimate customers' activity trajectories or zones based on the sparse check-in data. Beyond this estimation, a more challenging fact is that the geographical in uence is both customer-dependent and business-dependent. If a customer owns a car, he can visit a faraway business with less e ort than ones who cannot drive and rely on public transits. On the other hand, the geographical factor has di erent impacts on di erent types of businesses. For example, customers tend to visit nearby fast-food businesses for convenience. However, they may be willing to travel farther to visit other types of businesses, such as museums, where they are more closely connected with cultures and get inspirations, or salons where they can have their hair cut and styled by professionals.

• Reputation In uence. Nowadays, more and more customers rely on online reviews to get a sense of the reputation of local businesses. ese reviews implicitly in uence customers' decisions towards visiting a business. e in uence of reviews is also both customer-dependent and business-dependent. Di erent customers have di erent opinions on the same review. Moreover, similar reviews may have di erent impacts for di erent types of businesses. For example, a review such as 'A bit of long wait' to a fast-food business may give other customers a very negative impression. However, the impact may be milder if the comment is made on theme parks, such as Universal Studios.

In addition to the three challenges above, given the heterogeneous information on check-in, location, online reviews, current works also lack an integrated analysis of personal preferences, geographical in uence, and business reputation when modeling customers' decisions. To the best of our knowledge, this work is the rst one considering all these factors under the scenario of recommending customers for local businesses. To be more speci c, the main contributions of this work are as follows:

• We highlight the importance of recommending customers to local businesses. • We propose a customer recommendation model, CORALS, which, based on the historical check-in information, integrates customers' personal preferences, geographical in uence, and business reputation. In addition, the model is capable of quantifying the importance of these factors for di erent types of local businesses. • We present a comprehensive empirical evaluation of our approach against a number of recommendation methods on two real-world datasets. e results show that our approach, CORALS, outperforms all competitors in suggesting potential new customers for local businesses in di erent cities. We also demonstrate that the recommendation performance not only bene ts from geographical location, online reviews, etc., but can also be improved by smart parameter optimization methods that are suited for extremely sparse data.

e rest of this paper is organized as follows. We review the related work in Section 2. e details of CORALS is presented in Section 3, followed by the experimental evaluation in Section 4. Finally, Section 5 concludes this paper.

div.head: RELATED WORK
div.p: In this section, we discuss related works on the recommender system and location-based recommendation.

div.head: Recommender System
div.p: Recommendation approaches are grouped into three di erent categories: point-wise, pair-wise, and list-wise approaches from the perspective of learning to rank [25]. Point-wise approaches [16,28,36] reduce the ranking problems to either regression, classi cation, or ordinal regression problems. Maximum Margin Matrix Factorization (MMMF) [36] allows ordinal loss optimization for observed data. Weighed Regularized Matrix Factorization (WRMF) [16,28] introduces the preference con dence to conduct matrix factorization. Pair-wise approaches [30] reduce ranking to pair-wise classi cation problems. Bayesian Personalized Ranking (BPR) [30] is the rst one that optimizes the pair-wise error in ranking. Based on the intuition that top-ranked recommendations are more a ractive than low-ranked ones, list-wise approaches [32,35] directly optimize some information retrieval metrics and achieve list-wise loss minimization. Co Rank [35] and CLiMF [32] optimize Normalized Discounted Cumulative Gain (NDCG) and Mean Reciprocal Rank (MRR) to minimize the list-wise errors in ranking, respectively. [37] and [38] further propose Weighted Approximate-Rank Pairwise (WARP) loss and k-order statistic loss to optimize ranking, respectively. In addition, Factorization Machines and LightFM [17,29] can further utilize side features of users and items to augment the recommendation model. However, these recommender systems only optimize personal preferences based on observed check-ins and overlook the in uence of other sources of information, such as geographical and content information, which provide extra guidance in accurately understanding customers' decision-making processes.

div.head: Location-based Recommendation
div.p: Many recent studies [4,22,41,43] show that there is a strong correlation between customers' check-in activities and geographical distances. us leveraging geographical in uences to improve recommendation accuracies has been noticed by most of the current location-based recommendation work. For example, [4] rst detects multiple centers for each customer based on their check-in histories.

en it recommends a business with the probability that is inversely proportional to the distance between the location of the business and the nearest customer center. In [41], geographical in uence is modeled by a power-law distribution between the check-in probability and each pair-wise distance of two check-ins. [23,45] utilize the kernel density estimation to study customers' check-in and avoid employing a speci c distribution.

Collaborative ltering algorithm is also used to fuse the check-in and geographical information, such as POI popularity, social in uence, temporal in uence, and content information [11,12,14,14,19,21,24,41,43,44]. [11] conducts sentiment analysis on customers' comments to infer how good the POI is. [14,43] apply topic models to incorporate content information. [19] uses friendship to identify potential check-ins and optimizes POI recommendations based on observed check-ins, potential check-ins, and unobserved check-ins. [40] investigates the temporal matching between POI popularities and customer regularities to recommend POIs. To model customer's dynamic and sequential preferences, [39] developed a graph-based embedding model to learn the representations of POIs and recommend POIs. [26] developed a bi-weighted low-rank graph model to learn customer interests and their sequential preferences in a coherent way. More recently, several works [5,9,20,46] investigate the sequential pa erns among POIs in the historical check-in sequences to provide next POI recommendation.

To the best of our knowledge, all existing recommendation works in LBSN aim to recommend new POIs to customers. e goal in this work is the other way around, since we aim to help POIs, in particular, local businesses, identify potential new customers. e model proposed method, CARALS, not only provides an integrated analysis of the joint e ect of multiple factors, i.e. personal preference, geographical in uence, and business reputation, but also applies the state-of-the-art learning-to-rank strategy. Table 2 lists the notations we use in this paper. We use bold le ers for vectors and normal le ers for scalars.

In addition, the contributions of b,i and r b,i are given by w b and w r b , respectively. To optimize top ranked customers in the recommendation list, we apply the weighted approximate ranking strategy proposed in [37] to optimize precision@k 6 . Algorithm 1 summarizes the optimization process. First, the parameters Θ are initialized using Normal distributions. e optimization process is iterative. In each iteration, it goes through each observed check-in in the training set. For each observed check-in (b, i), we sample a random customer j who has not visited business b. If the preference order between i and j on business b is correctly predicted using the current Θ, we skip this pair and randomly sample another customer to nd a violation. is process repeats at most S max times until we nd such a violation. Once we nd a violation, we update the corresponding parameter θ , θ ∈ Θ. A er iterating through each check-in in the training set, we evaluate the performance using the validation set. If the performance increases, we accept the updates on Θ. Otherwise, we reject the updates. e optimization terminates when iter reaches the maximum number of iterations. As we mentioned in the introduction, since many businesses and customers have limited numbers of check-ins, the check-in data is extremely sparse. However, the parameters of these businesses and customers can be immensely useful and informative to the problem we want to optimize. To e ectively leverage the sparse data, AdaGrad [8] is proposed to give a higher learning rate to the parameters that are more sparse in the data. We adopt this concept to adjust the learning rate adaptively for each individual parameter θ , which is shown in lines 10-13 of Algorithm 1. AdaGrad modi es the general learning rate η at each time step ts for every parameter θ based on the past gradients that have been computed for θ . n t s+1 θ records the sum of the squares of the gradients with respect to θ up to the ts t h time step 7 . ϵ is a smoothing term that avoids division by zero. In this way, AdaGrad makes it such that parameters that are more sparse in the data have a higher learning rate which translates into a larger update for that parameter.
In one iteration, the same parameter may be optimized multiple times. Each optimization counts 1 time step.

div.head: Business Reputation Inference from Reviews
div.p: In this section, we discuss how to model the business reputation, u b , based on the reviews commented on the local businesses. ere are two main challenges. First, reviews di er in their lengths. Some reviews are informative and have more words while others are not. is challenge makes it di cult to model the business's reputation u b in a xed-length vector. Second, for a particular business, some reviews are older while others are more recent. ey may have di erent in uences on the reputation of the business. To solve the rst challenge, we apply the "paragraph vector" technique, a distributed memory model, proposed in [18]. Figure 1 shows the well-known framework for the vector learning task, which is to predict a word given other words in a context.
Formally, given a sequence of training words o 1 , o 2 , o 3 , …, o H , the objective of the paragraph vector model is to maximize the average log probability H
div.formula: H −k h=k lo p(o h |o h−k , ..., o h+k ).
div.p: e prediction task is performed via a multiclass classi er, i.e., so max. en, we have:
div.formula: p(o h |o h−k , ..., o h+k ) = e o h o e o .
div.p: Each o h is the un-normalized log probability for each output word o h , calculated as:
div.formula: o h = V 0 + V z(o h−k , ..., o h+k , U ),
div.p: where V 0 and V are the so max parameters. z is constructed by a concatenation of a review vector and word vectors from O. Both review and word vectors are trained using stochastic gradient descent (SGD) and the gradient is obtained via back propagation. At each step of SGD, we sample a xed-length context from a random review, compute the error gradient and update the parameters in the model. Once the parameters get converged, we obtain the dense representation of each review. In order to address the impact of the chronological order of the reviews, we use the vector of the most recent review as the reputation vector of the business, u b .

div.head: EXPERIMENTS
div.p: In this section, we conduct extensive experiments on two real-world datasets to evaluate the performance of CORALS.

div.head: Datasets and Experimental Settings
div.p: e experiments are conducted on two datasets. One is the most recently released dataset from the Yelp challenge . e other is a Foursquare dataset 9 . e Yelp dataset contains interactions between customers and businesses in 12 major cities. ere are 4.1M reviews and 947K tips by 1M users for 144K businesses. Among the 12 cities, we select seven cities which have abundant check-ins to conduct the experiments. e Foursquare dataset contains interactions between customers and businesses in Los Angeles and New York. Table 3 shows the statistics for the nine cities in the two datasets.

Unfortunately, some businesses do not accumulate an adequate amount of check-ins. Moreover, some customers lack su cient check-ins to infer their preferences. We follow the data cleaning strategy in [15] and lter out businesses and customers whose check-ins are less than 20 for the Yelp dataset. For the Foursquare dataset, we follow the cleaning steps in [3] and remove business and customers that have less than eight check-ins. For each business, its check-ins are sorted in chronological order based on the timestamps. e rst 50% of the check-ins are used as the training data. e following 20% are used as the validation data and the remaining 30% are used as the test data for evaluation.

In the experiments, the parameters η, ϵ, iter max , S max , λ p , λ q , λ d , λ w , and λ w r are set to 0.001, 10 −6 , 500, 100, 1, 1, 1, 0.1, and 0.1, respectively. e dimensions of p, q, and d are set to 10, 10, 20, respectively.

div.head: Baselines
div.p: To compare our approach with others, the following nine methods are adopted as baselines.

• Weighted Regularized MF (WRMF). WRMF [16] minimizes the square error loss by assigning both observed and unobserved check-ins with di erent con dential values based on matrix factorization. • Maximum Margin MF (MMMF). MMMF [36] optimizes customer preferences via a hinge loss, which is as follows:
div.formula: argmin P, Q (b, i, j ) max (0, 1 − p b • (q i − q j )) 2 + λ 2 ( P 2 + Q 2 )
div.p: • Bayesian Personalized Ranking MF (BPRMF). In order to ameliorate the order of customers' preferences, BPRMF [30] optimizes Area Under the Curve (AUC) based on observed checkins and sampled unobserved check-ins. • Co Rank. Co Rank [35] optimizes the estimation of a ranking loss based on Normalized Discounted Cumulative Gain (NDCG). • CLiMF. CLiMF [32] optimizes a di erent ranking-oriented loss, i.e., Mean Reciprocal Rank (MRR) loss. • WARP. In [37], Weighted Approximate-Rank Pairwise loss, a variant of AUC loss, is proposed to optimize precision@k. WARP loss di ers from AUC loss in updating parameters. WARP keeps In addition to the above competitors, we also implement CORALS with two other gradient-based parameter optimization strategies, i.e. SGD and RMSprop [13].

• CORALS-SGD. CORALS-SGD applies SGD to conduct optimizations. All parameters share the same learning rate. • CORALS-RMSprop. RMSprop [13] is applied to conduct optimizations. RMSprop is an adaptive learning rate method and is used to resolve the problem of AdaGrad's radically diminishing learning rates.

div.head: Recommendation Performance
div.p: In this section, we evaluate the performances of CORALS and its variants against the nine baseline methods. For customer recommendations, local businesses can send a bunch of coupons to the targeted customers. erefore, we adopt MAP as the evaluation metric. Given a ranked list rl of potential new customers, the average precision for a business b is:

div.p: where ω is the number of new customers who visit a business b in the test set, po denotes the position in the ranked list rl and |rl | gives the total number of potential new customers in rl. Customers are ranked decreasingly based on how likely they will come in rl. precision(pos) is the precision of a cut-o rank list from 1 to pos, and rel(pos) is an indicator function that equals to 1 if the customer visits b in the test set, otherwise equals to 0. In addition, we further show the average recommendation performances for the top (10%) and tail (10%) businesses 11 in each city to demonstrate how each method performs when there is a relatively rich and poor amount of checkins, respectively. For example, WRMF achieves 0.026 on average for all businesses in Charlo e. It achieves 0.058 and 0.014 on average for the top and tail businesses in Pi sburgh, respectively. We observe that the more check-ins we have for businesses, the more accurate recommendations we can achieve.
is observation applies to businesses in almost all the nine cities under the 12 methods.

MMMF, BPRMF, Co Rank, CLiMF, WARP, and kOS achieve better recommendation performances than WRMF in general. is veri es that methods achieving low predition errors do not necessarily have high recommendation accuracies. In other words, directly optimizing the predicted check-ins may not always provide the best recommendation lists to businesses. Co Rank, CLiMF, WARP, and kOS further outperform MMMF and BPRMF due to their optimizing strategies. ey optimize NDCG, MRR, precision@k, and precision@k, respectively, which all focus on be er optimizing the top-ranked customers in the list. BPRMF, which optimizes AUC, focuses on optimizing the entire list of customers. Co Rank, CLiMF, WARP and kOS outperform USG, which shows the advantage of the state-of-the-art learning-to-rank recommendation methods. Even without utilizing location and social information, they can accurately infer customers' preferences and achieve good recommendation performances.

It demonstrates that recommender algorithms in LSBN can also bene t greatly from suitable parameter learning strategies. Bold numbers in Table 4 indicate the winners for the same city and the same group of the business. For example, the mean MAPs in Charlo e are 0.026, 0.028, 0.029, 0.031, 0.034, 0.044, 0.038, 0.029, 0.027, 0.052, 0.051, 0.051 for WRMF, MMMF, BPRMF, Co Rank, CLiMF, WARP, kOS, USG, ASMF, CORALS-AdaGrad, CORALS-RMSprop, and CORALS-SGD, respectively. Among all these 12 scores, 0.052 is the highest; hence it is the winner and highlighted in bold. In summary, CORALS-AdaGrad or its variants win in all scenarios except in Las Vegas where WARP and ASMF score slightly be er and in New York where ASMF scores slightly be er on the top businesses.

div.head: Geographical Preference Inference
div.p: In this section, we will use examples to verify that the geographical in uence is both business-dependent and customer-dependent.

We rst use three case examples to show the geographical in uence on di erent types of local businesses. We select three local businesses in Phoenix, i.e. Phoenix Art Museum, a branch of Mc-Donald's, and Alo Cafe. Figures 2a, 2b, 2c show the locations of the three businesses, represented by a blue mark each, together with the heat maps of their visitors. e location of a visitor is estimated by the average of all locations he/she has visited. ere are two interesting observations. First, Phoenix Art Museum has more check-ins than McDonald's and Alo Cafe do. Second, the majority of the check-ins of McDonald's and Alo Cafe come from their nearby regions while the visitors of Phoenix Art Museum are sca ered in the entire Phoenix. In addition, the number of museums in Phoenix is much fewer than the numbers of fast-food businesses and cafes. e rationale behind the observations is that people tend to get services from nearby businesses if the services are available since it takes less e ort. However, for some business that is only available in a remote location, the customers may be more tolerant to travel a long distance. erefore, businesses such as fast-food and cafes get in uenced more by the geographical convenience than businesses like museums. In CORALS, parameter w b is used to model the geographical in uence on a business b. Higher values of w b indicate greater in uences on the geographical convenience. In Section 4.6, we will show a detailed analysis of w b on various types of local businesses.

en, we study the geographical in uence on individual customers. We randomly sample two customers from Las Vegas and plot their check-ins in Figures 4a and 4b, respectively. We observe that the two customers have their own exploration preferences. User 1 tends to explore the main street in Las Vegas, while user 2 not only explores the main street but also checks in at the northwestern region of Las Vegas. Given a local business b, represented by the black marker, GMM tells b,u 1 < b,u 2 , which indicates that business b is more geographically convenient for user 2. e pairwise geographical convenience information, embedded in the GMM, helps CORALS be er understand customers' decision-making processes from the perspective of the convenience of the local businesses.

Note that for each customer, we group his/her check-ins by a nity propagation to derive the number of components in the GMM. Figure 3 shows the customer percentage distributions over the number of exploration centers in di erent cities. We observe that most customers have only one or two exploration centers. e rationale behind it is that most customers tend to explore around

div.head: Reputation In uence Analysis
div.p: In this section, we investigate how the MAP performance of CORALS changes with the number of reviews considered when constructing businesses' reputation vectors. First, we do not incorporate any reviews, notated as 0 reviews. en, we use 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, and 11 most recent reviews to construct the reputation vectors of businesses, respectively. Figure 5 shows the performance of CORALS (measured by MAP) on the nine cities. In particular, the performance on the Yelp dataset is plo ed in solid lines, while the performance on the Foursquare dataset is plo ed in dashed lines. When we ignore review information in the model, the performance is relatively poor. As long as we incorporate the information of the most recent review, the performance improves. For example, the performance increases from 0.081 to 0.097 for Madison. However, when we incorporate more reviews to construct reputation vectors, the performance gain is marginal. is is mainly due to the fact that customers only read a couple of the most recent reviews to perceive the reputation of the local business.

div.head: Analysis on Contributions of Geographical Convenience and Reputation Reliance
div.p: In this section, we will analyze to what extent the geographical convenience and online reviews in uence customers' decisions in visiting various types of local businesses. We look into ve types of local businesses, i.e. fast-food, bar, cafe, salon, and museum in the two largest cities, i.e., Phoenix and Las Vegas, in terms of the number of customers and businesses. e type of the business is inferred from the name of the business. If the name of the business contains "burger", "Mcdonald's', or "KFC", the business is tagged as a fast-food business. If the name contains "bar" or "pub", the business is tagged as a bar business. If the name of the business contains "cafe", "co ee" or "starbucks", it falls into a cafe business. If the name contains "salon", it belongs to a salon business. If the name contains "museum", it belongs to a museum business. For each type of businesses, we look into their geographical in uence weights w and reputation in uence weights w r , and calculate the type-wise median of the in uence weights. Table 5 shows the analysis based on the businesses in Phoenix. ere are 144 fast-food, 302 bar, 394 cafe, 144 salon, and 8 museum businesses. e geographical in uence for fast-food, bar, and cafe businesses are all around 0.316. For salons, the low geographical in uence weight, 0.306, indicates that customers are willing to travel a li le bit farther for be er haircare services. For museums, which are fewer in quantity, customers have to travel farther compared with other types of businesses. e geographical in uence decreases to 0.248. Moreover, the reputation also has distinct in uences on di erent types of businesses. e reviews on fast-food, bar, and cafe businesses have relatively small in uence on customers' decisions Table 6 shows the same analysis based on the businesses in Las Vegas, which is consistent with most discoveries in Phoenix. ere is one interesting discovery about the geographical in uence on bars in Las Vegas, which indicates that customers in Las Vegas are more willing to take more e ort in visiting faraway bars compared with fast-food, cafe, and even salon businesses. e rationale behind it is that there are many a ractive shows and events in Las Vegas bars.

div.head: CONCLUSION AND FUTURE WORK
div.p: In this work, we study the problem of recommending customers to local businesses in LBSN. We look into the customers' decisionmaking processes and propose a model, CORALS, which integrates customers' personal preferences, geographical in uence, and businesses' reputation. We conduct extensive experiments to demonstrate the e ectiveness of CORALS comparing to nine di erent baseline methods on two real-world datasets. We further demonstrate that the customer recommendation task in LSBN bene ts from not only heterogeneous information, but also advanced suitable parameter learning strategies for sparse data. In the future, we will further investigate the in uence of online photos, since one photo can convey much powerful information than a thousand words.
